_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Facility Accidental Release Policy
The owners, management, and employees of UAP Distribution's Moses Lake facility, located at 2624 Road "N" NE in Moses Lake, Washington, are committed to the prevention of any accidental release of anhydrous ammonia.  If an accidental release should occur, the facility is prepared to work with the local fire department and other authorities to mitigate any release and minimize the impact to human health and the environment.  A detailed response plan has been developed and will be implemented in the event of an accidental release.  

Facility Information
The primary activity at the facility is the storage and sale of fertilizer.  The substance occasionally stored at this facility above the RMP threshold is anhydrous ammonia.  Anhydrous ammonia is received via rail car and reacts with phosphoric acid to produce ammonia polyphosphate fertilizer.  The end product is nonhazardous.  The fertilizer is utilized in land application for crop production.  The mobile reactor used in this process is not the property of UAP Distribution, Inc.  The reactor is owned by a private companythat travels to various locationproviding the service to retail fertilizer locations.  No employee of UAP Distribution is involved in the processing.

Emergency Response Program
The facility has developed a written Emergency Response Plan.  The Plan addresses the regulations concerning emergency plans as mandated by OSHA, DOT/RSPA, and EPA.  The plan addresses actions to be taken in various emergency situation.  The plan includes emergency contact information (both internal and external),  arrangements with local authorities, emergency action procedures, fire preventions, the spill policy, the closure plan, and more.  The plan also include employee training.  

Accidental Release Prevention Program
The users of anhydrous ammonia at the facility implement the provisions of the following:
     Safety Requirements for Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia - ANSI K61

.1
     Unfired Pressure Vessel Safety Orders - California Code of Regulations
     Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia 29 CFR 1910.111

Five Year Accident History
There have bee no accidental releases or near misses at this facility in the past five years that have caused any deaths, injuries, evacuations, environmental damage, or significant property damage on site or off site.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety
Safety improvements are on going at this facility.  Periodic evaluations are performed to assess the facility.
